Unnamed: 2: Laying bricks (baked bricks or dried mud bricks or breeze blocks) with mortar to form a wall

Walls composed of wet mud (sediment possibly bonded with straw, lime, or sand, mixed with water). Constructed without shutters in layers. The layers are applied wet and left to dry before applying the next layer. In MENA archaeological literature this is often referred to as "pisé".
Laying stones to form a wall without the use of mortar.
Laying stones to form a wall, bonded with mortar.
Laying stone to form a wall.
Inlaid surface decoration for floors and walls formed by small pieces of stone, glass or ceramic.
Laying a pavement or similar surface.
Applying a coat on other building material to make to surface smooth.
Normally of concrete
Walls composed of wet mud (sediment, possibly bonded with straw or other vegetal matter, lime, or sand, mixed with water). Constructed with shutters to keep the mud in place while it is still wet.
Covering with a dome shaped roof
Covering with a flat shaped roof
Covering with a sloping roof
Covering with a vault shaped roof
Double laid (masonry) wall, ofen of stone, filled in the middle with earth/small stone rubble
Fine plaster used for covering walls and for making decorations (cornices, mouldings, etc.)
Overlaying a roof with tiles
Overlaying a wall or floor with tiles

Making something water resistant by applying waterproof material
Mixture of twigs, earth, clay and mud
Timber framing
